title: Borderlands 3 review: puerile, repetitive, reductive... and I absolutely love it
text:
Is there anything more pernicious in modern cultural criticism than the concept of a guilty pleasure? The very idea that one should somehow feel shame for deriving enjoyment from a product or a piece of art just because it contradicts the consensus - or, indeed, anyone else’s opinion - is fundamentally hateful.

If one believes something to be good then it’s good, no matter how hard the prevailing tastemakers of the age argue against it. Conventional wisdom? As no lesser wit than Sid Vicious once put it when asked how the man in the street would react to his latest outrage, ‘I’ve met the man in the street - and he’s a ****’.

And yet… What if that product or piece of art contravenes one’s own thresholds?

Gearbox’s sci-fi loot shooter series Borderlands 3 is puerile in tone, repetitive to play and utter reductive. This third instalment proper particularly so; a few minor tweaks and improvements aside, it essentially offers the exact same experience its predecessor did seven years and one entire gaming generation ago. It’s a one note take on a one-dimensional idea and… I absolutely love it.
